questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the given image is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: It can cause death through asphyxia and vagal inhibition, requiring at least 2 minutes of pressure.

options.label: B
options.text: Results in minimal visible injuries on the neck.

options.label: C
options.text: Key postmortem findings include only superficial bruises and no internal injuries.

questions.correct_answer: A. It can cause death through asphyxia and vagal inhibition, requiring at least 2 minutes of pressure.
questions.explanation:
Examination Type

Findings

External Examination

(Option B ruled out)
  • Bruises and Abrasions: On the front and sides of the neck.
  • Signs of Asphyxia: Cyanosis, facial swelling, Tardieu's spots, bleeding from nose and ears.
  • Injuries on Other Body Parts: Additional signs of violence (abrasions, bruises, scratches).

Internal Examination (Option C ruled out)
  • Haemorrhages: In subcutaneous tissues under bruises.
  • Muscle Damage: Tears or lacerations in neck muscles.
  • Hyoid Bone Fracture: Significant diagnostic indicator, typically from inward compression.
  • Laryngeal and Tracheal Damage: Fractures of thyroid and potentially cricoid cartilages.
  • Haemorrhages in Mouth/Throat: Bruising and lacerations on the tongue, haemorrhages in mucous membranes.

questions.text: A forensic pathologist examines a drowning victim’s dead body and conducts tests for diatoms and chloride levels in the heart. The victim was found in a lake, and a water sample from the scene was collected for analysis. Which of the following statements is false ?

options.label: A
options.text: In freshwater drowning, chloride levels in the left heart are lower.

options.label: B
options.text: In saltwater drowning, chloride levels in the left heart are higher.

options.label: C
options.text: Finding diatoms in bone marrow indicates that the individual ingested water while alive.

options.label: D
options.text: The absence of diatoms in tissues can definitively rule out drowning.

questions.correct_answer: D. The absence of diatoms in tissues can definitively rule out drowning.
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Diatom Test

Gettler Test

Features
  • Diatoms are microscopic unicellular algae with silicon skeletons that are chemically inert and resistant to strong acids.
  • In antemortem drowning, diatoms enter the bloodstream through ruptured alveolar walls, reaching organs like the lungs, heart, brain, liver, and bone marrow.
  • Diatoms resist putrefaction, making the test useful even in decomposed bodies.
  • A 50g tissue sample is treated with nitric acid and examined for diatoms.
    • A water sample from the drowning site is collected for comparison of diatom species and proportions.
  • Limitations: Possible contamination from food, air, or environment.
    • The test cannot rule out contamination, but it is still the "gold standard" for diagnosing typical drowning.
  • Normal Chloride Levels: The chloride content in the right and left sides of the heart is typically similar, around 600 mg/100 ml.
  • A 25 mg% or more difference in chloride levels between the two sides suggests antemortem drowning.

Interpretation
  • Presence: Finding diatoms in tissues (bone marrow, blood, etc.) strongly indicates antemortem drowning, suggesting the individual inhales diatom-rich water. Detection in multiple tissues enhances reliability, indicating systemic absorption and confirming drowning. (Option C ruled out)
  • Absence: While the absence of diatoms does not rule out drowning, it raises questions about the death's circumstances. Prior water ingestion or contact with diatom-rich environments could allow diatoms to enter circulation without drowning.
  • Freshwater Drowning: The chloride content in the left heart is lower than in the right heart due to dilution from the water. (Option A ruled out)
  • Saltwater Drowning: In saltwater drowning, the chloride content in the left heart is higher than in the right heart due to hemoconcentration and mixing with saltwater. (Option B ruled out)
  • No Change in Chloride Content: Observed in deaths from laryngeal spasm, vagal inhibition, putrefaction, patent foramen ovale, or when the saline content of the drowning medium is similar to that of blood.

questions.text: Match the following signs of drowning. 1. Sehrt's Sign a) Free liquid in the paranasal sinus. 2. Sveshnikov's sign b) Water in the middle ear due to violent respiratory efforts while drowning. 3. Sabinsky's Sign c) Micro rupture in gastric mucosa due to stretching. 4. Ueno's Sign d) Small and anaemic spleen due to vasoconstriction.
questions.explanation:
References:

  • ↳ Reference:

Signs in Drowning

Sehrt's Sign

Micro rupture in gastric mucosa due to over-stretching on ingestion of fluid.

Sveshnikov's sign

Free liquid in the paranasal sinus.

Sabinsky's Sign

Small and anemic spleen due to vasoconstriction.

Ueno's Sign

Water in the middle ear due to violent respiratory efforts while drowning.

Wydler's Sign

Gastric content in a container with three layers (Foam- top, liquid- middle, solid- bottom).

Drowning Index

Weight of both lungs + weight of pleural effusion / Weight of spleen

If > 14.1%, it suggests AM drowning.

questions.text: A forensic pathologist is conducting an autopsy on a body recovered from a body of water. During the examination, several findings are noted. Based on the following statements regarding postmortem findings in drowning, which of the following is true? Frothy fluid, resulting from the churning of water, mucus, and air, is present at the mouth and nostrils, indicating drowning. Cutis anserina indicates prolonged immersion in warm water. Washerwoman’s hand appears as wrinkled and sodden skin due to prolonged submersion. A cadaveric spasm is the immediate stiffening of muscles holding debris, indicating drowning. Paltauf’s hemorrhage is a postmortem finding not associated with drowning. Water and bleeding in the middle ear confirm antemortem drowning. The heart shows equal amounts of blood on both sides in drowning victims.
questions.explanation:
PM Findings in Drowning

External Findings

Internal Findings

Pale & cyanosed face from putrefaction.

 

Eyes half-open/closed, suffused conjunctiva, dilated pupils, subconjunctival hemorrhages (Antemortem drowning).

 

Froth: Fine, copious, tenacious, lathery froth at mouth and nostrils is characteristic of antemortem drowning, and reappears after wiping or chest pressure.

  • Mechanism: The churning of water, mucus, and retained air in airways creates froth. (Statement 1)
  • In other conditions like strangulation, and electric shock, the froth is not as fine or tenacious.
 

Cutis anserina (goose flesh): The puckered appearance of skin due to the contraction of erector muscles in cold water, occurs immediately after antemortem submersion or by rigor mortis. (Statement 2)

 

Washerwomen’s hand: Wrinkled, sodden, and bleached appearance of hands and feet due to prolonged submersion, occurring postmortem in 3–4 hours and fully affecting the hands by 24 hours. (Statement 3)

 

Cadaveric spasm: Immediate stiffening of muscles holding grass, sand, or debris in clenched hands—antemortem proof of drowning. (Statement 4)

 

Rigor mortis appears early after a violent struggle (Antemortem drowning).

Lungs: Ballooning with frothy fluid, rib indentations, heavy and waterlogged.

  • Paltauf's hemorrhage: Red-gray mottling with areas of hemorrhage due to effusion of blood along interlobular septa. (Statement 5)
 

Heart: Right side full of dark venous blood, left side empty (a sign of asphyxia). (Statement 7)

  • Gettler test: Measures chloride content to differentiate antemortem drowning.
    • Freshwater: Lower chloride in the left heart.
    • Saltwater: Higher chloride in the left heart.
 

Stomach: Water is present in 70% of cases, indicating antemortem drowning if liquid was not swallowed voluntarily.

 

Brain: Congested with softened grey-white junction (Antemortem).

 

Middle ear: The presence of water and bleeding in the middle ear confirms antemortem drowning. (Statement 6)

 

Diatom test: The presence of diatoms in lungs and bone marrow suggests antemortem drowning.

questions.text: A 30 y/o man is found dead after an incident where he fell into cold water. Witnesses report that he surfaced briefly, then collapsed and became unresponsive. No significant water is found in his lungs upon autopsy, but signs of cardiac arrest are evident. Which of the following is the most likely cause of death?
questions.explanation:
Type of Drowning

Features

Dry Drowning

(Option C ruled out)
  • Definition: Death from laryngeal spasm with minimal water entering the lungs.
  • Mechanism:
    • Asphyxia occurs without significant water inhalation.
    • Diagnosis is made by inference and exclusion, as no anatomical evidence is present.
  • Occurrence:
    • May occur with relatively dry lungs if circulation continues briefly after water removal.
    • Resuscitative efforts may lead to water absorption into hypertonic plasma, keeping lungs distended.
    • Laryngeal spasm may prevent further water entry, allowing circulatory function to clear intra-alveolar fluid.

Hydrocution (Immersion Syndrome)
  • Definition: Sudden death due to cardiac arrest from vagal inhibition caused by cold water exposure.
  • Mechanism:
    • Cold water stimulates nerve endings on the skin.
    • Water impact on the epigastrium can trigger the vagal reflex.
    • Cold water in the ear, nasal passages, pharynx, and larynx stimulates mucosal nerve endings.
  • Risk Factors:
    • Inexperienced divers or those diving feet first.
    • Alcohol consumption increases the risk due to vasodilation.

Near/Post Immersion Syndrome (Secondary Drowning)
(Option D ruled out)
  • Definition: Refers to a submersion victim resuscitated and surviving for 24 hours.
  • Complications:
    • Hypoxemia leads to potential brain damage.
    • Electrolyte disturbances and pulmonary oedema.
    • Haemoglobinuria, sepsis-pneumonia, metabolic acidosis, and chemical pneumonitis.
    • Cerebral oedema, cardiac arrhythmias, and myocardial anoxia.

questions.text: A 25 y/o man is found dead near a water body after being submerged for an unknown period. Autopsy reveals ballooned, pale pink lungs that retain their shape and do not collapse after removal. Blood tests show significant hyponatremia and hyperkalemia. Which of the following best describes his condition?
questions.explanation:
Features

Freshwater Drowning

Seawater Drowning
(Option B ruled out)

Pathophysiology
  • Haemodilution: Inhalation increases blood volume by 50%, causing anemia, hemolysis, and myocardial hypoxia.
  • Electrolyte Changes: Marked hyponatremia and hyperkalemia; calcium decrease leads to arrhythmias.
  • Surfactant Dysfunction: Freshwater denatures the surfactant which causes alveolar collapse and pulmonary oedema.
  • Cardiac Load: Increased pulmonary oedema and electrolyte imbalances decrease cardiac output and cause hypotension.
  • Haemoconcentration: High salinity (≥3% NaCl) draws water into the lungs, causing severe pulmonary oedema and elevated plasma sodium.
  • Electrolyte Changes: Increased blood viscosity leads to bradycardia and myocardial failure; altered potassium and sodium levels(hypernatremia)
  • Red Cell Changes: Crenation of red blood cells impairs oxygen transport.
  • Myocardial Anoxia: Asphyxia from pulmonary oedema and cardiac stress results in hypoxia and potential arrest.

Lung characteristics
  • Size: Ballooned but light; pale pink colour; emphysematous consistency.
  • Shape after Removal: Retained, no collapse; crepitus with little froth and no fluid.
  • Size: Ballooned and heavy; purplish or bluish colour; soft, jelly-like consistency.
  • Shape after Removal: Flattened; no crepitus; copious fluid and froth.

Fatal period
  • Death typically occurs within 4-5 minutes
  • Death may take 8-10 minutes.

questions.text: A 3-month-old infant is found unresponsive in bed next to a sleeping adult who has a strong odor of alcohol. The infant's nose appears flattened, and there are pale areas around the face. Which type of suffocation is most likely responsible for the infant's death?
questions.explanation:
Overlaying

Burking

Wedging
  • Definition: Compression suffocation due to the weight of an adult (e.g., mother) on an infant during sleep.
  • Mechanism:
    • Limits thoracic movements, reducing or preventing respiratory exchange.
    • Commonly occurs when the adult is under the influence of alcohol.
  • Findings:
    • May show flattening of the nose and face.
    • The pale appearance of the affected areas; nostrils may be filled with frothy, possibly blood-stained fluid.
    • Typical signs of asphyxia.
  • Cause of Death: May result from neurogenic cardiac arrest
  • Definition: A method of homicidal smothering and traumatic asphyxia.
  • Historical Context:
    • Named after William Burke and William Hare, who killed 16 people in the late 1820s in Edinburgh for anatomical dissection.
  • Method:
    • Victims were lured, given alcohol, and then subdued by kneeling or sitting on their chests to close their mouths and noses.
    • One accomplice would drag the victim's body, aiding in concealment. (Option A ruled out)
  • Definition: Suffocation caused by the body being compressed between two firm surfaces.
  • Common Observations:
    • Often seen in children.
  • Mechanism: Prevents normal breathing due to the physical pressure from both sides.

questions.text: A 28 y/o construction worker is trapped under a heavy beam and found unresponsive. He has deep purple discolouration above the compression point, pale skin below, and petechiae on his face and neck. He is pronounced dead at the scene. What type of asphyxia is most likely?
questions.explanation:
Features

Traumatic Asphyxia

Positional Asphyxia

(Option B ruled out)

Definition
  • Respiratory arrest due to mechanical fixation of the chest by unyielding substances or external pressure. (Perthe’s syndrome)
  • Asphyxia results from the body being in a position that impairs breathing, often due to neck twisting or compression of the trachea.

Mechanism
  • Prevents normal chest wall movements, leading to respiratory failure.
  • Often associated with significant compression of the chest and abdomen
  • Abdominal weight compresses the diaphragm, hindering thoracic organ function and respiratory movement.
  • Impaired venous return to the heart can contribute to asphyxia.

Common Causes
  • Crowded situations leading to trampling
  • Crushing accidents (e.g., falls of earth/stones in mines, building collapses).
  • Heavy objects (e.g., vehicles or machinery) pressing on the body.
  • Physical restraint in a prone position (face down).
  • Falling and wedging in a well or narrow space.
  • Indirect compression (jack-knife position) where thighs and knees push against the chest.

Postmortem Findings
  • Intense congestion and petechial hemorrhages in the head, neck, and upper chest.
  • Skin colour above the compression level: deep purple or purple-red; below this level: pale or mildly cyanosed.-Masque ecchymotique
  • Swelling, congestion, and petechiae on the face, lips, and scalp.

 

 
  • Marked congestion and cyanosis in the face and neck.
  • Presence of petechiae on the face.

questions.text: Which of the following methods of suffocation is most commonly associated with a reflex vagal inhibition that can lead to sudden cardiac arrest?
questions.explanation:
Methods of Suffocation

Features

Smothering

(Option A ruled out)
  • Definition: Closing the nose and mouth using hands or foreign substances (e.g., mud, cloth).
  • Autopsy Findings:
    • External: Pallor may be present around the mouth/nose, pressure marks, distinct nail marks, petechiae, contusion on the inner lip, and stains on the bedding.
    • Internal: Potential internal organ haemorrhages.

Gagging (Option B ruled out)
  • Definition: Asphyxia caused by a cloth or material obstructing the mouth and nose.
  • Mechanism: A gag can block the pharynx, initially allowing nasal airflow. Obstruction worsens due to saliva and mucus, leading to complete airway blockage.
  • Symptoms:
    • Facial congestion.
    • Fine petechiae on the face, sclerae, and conjunctivae.
  • Intent: Always homicidal.

Choking

(Option C ruled out)
  • Definition: Airway obstruction due to an object lodged in the hypopharynx.
  • Accidental Choking: Often occurs during meals, especially while laughing or crying; vomited matter may be inhaled under intoxication or unconsciousness.
  • Immediate Symptoms: Acute respiratory distress; complications may develop later.
  • Autopsy Findings:
    • Thickened epiglottis and folds
    • Mucus accumulation in the throat.
    • Lungs exhibit interalveolar oedema, congestion, and haemorrhages.

Café Coronary
  • Definition: Sudden collapse and death while eating, often in intoxicated individuals.
  • Symptoms:
    • Cyanosis and violent coughing.
    • Collapse without significant distress.
  • Cause of Death: Reflex vagal inhibition leading to sudden cardiac arrest; high blood alcohol content anaesthetises the gag reflex. A poorly chewed food bolus may obstruct the larynx.
  • Autopsy Findings: Obstruction may be found in the mouth, larynx, or trachea, with food particles in mucus in the trachea/bronchi, differentiating from cases of post-mortem oesophagal food forcing. Signs of asphyxia may be absent.

  • Treatment: Heimlich Maneuver: Stand behind the patient, interlock fingers, and apply pressure to the stomach.

questions.text: A 35 y/o man is found unresponsive in his apartment. The scene suggests possible asphyxia due to a hanging. Upon examination, the forensic team notes several physical findings. Which of the following findings would most likely not be observed in this case of asphyxial death?

options.label: B
options.text: Bright red discolouration of the skin

questions.correct_answer: B. Bright red discolouration of the skin

questions.text: Which of the following findings is most characteristic of ligature strangulation?

options.label: A
options.text: Distinct bruising of subcutaneous tissues beneath the ligature

options.label: B
options.text: Presence of Tardieu's spots primarily on the chest and abdomen

options.label: D
options.text: Absence of postmortem staining above the ligature

questions.correct_answer: A. Distinct bruising of subcutaneous tissues beneath the ligature
questions.explanation:
Finding

Description

Face
  • Congested, swollen, and cyanosed.
  • Tardieu's spots (petechiae) on the forehead, temples, eyelids, and conjunctiva. (Option B ruled out)
  • Prominent eyes with congested conjunctiva, dilated pupils, and possible subconjunctival haemorrhages.
  • Cyanosis of lips, fingernails, and earlobes.
  • Postmortem staining above the ligature. (Option D ruled out)
  • Swollen, dark-coloured, protruding tongue, possibly bitten.
  • Bloodstained frothy fluid and mucus in mouth and nostrils.

Neck
  • Ligature mark ('furrow'): well-defined groove, typically the same width as the ligature, often horizontal.
  • More prominent on the front and sides of the neck.
  • Red base with congested or ecchymosed margins; imprint pattern may be present.
  • Can be indistinct if the ligature is soft; it may appear as a deep groove with a narrow cord ('cheese cutter method').
  • May show an oblique appearance if the victim was dragged post-strangulation.

Other Body Parts
  • Deep, prominent postmortem staining.
  • Involuntary discharge of urine and faecal matter; less common seminal ejaculation.
  • Clenched hands; possible genital turgidity.
  • Possible abrasions, fingernail marks, and contusions on face, and arms, indicating struggle.
  • Horizontal, irregular abrasions on the neck may indicate attempts to remove ligature.

Feature

Hanging

Strangulation

Face

Usually, pale, petechiae are less common

Congested, livid with petechiae

Tongue swelling and protrusion

Less marked

More marked

Bleeding from nose, ears, mouth

Less common

More common

Ligature mark ('furrow')

  • Direction
  • Continuity
  • Level in the neck
  • Base
  • Oblique
  • Noncontinuous
  • Above thyroid
  • Pale, hard, parchment-like
  • Transverse
  • Continuous
  • Below thyroid
  • Soft and reddish

Abrasions and ecchymoses about the edges of the mark

Not common

Common

Involuntary discharge of feces and urine

Less common

More common

Involuntary discharge of seminal fluid

More common

Less common

Bruising of neck muscles

Less common

More common

Subcutaneous tissue under the mark

White, hard, glistening

Ecchymosed

Hyoid bone fracture

May occur

Uncommon

Thyroid fracture

Unlikely

More common

Larynx and trachea fracture

Unlikely

May be found

Emphysematous bullae on lungs

Sometimes present

Very common

Carotid arteries

Damage may be seen in the intima

Rare

Design

History of previous unsuccessful attempts of suicide may be available

No such history is available

Signs of struggle

Absent

Always present, unless taken unaware

questions.text: A 45 y/o man is found unconscious in an alley with marks around his neck suggesting strangulation. The police suspect the use of a ligature tightened rapidly with a lever. Which of the following types of strangulation best describes this scenario?
questions.explanation:
Type

Description

Manual Strangulation (Throttling) (Option A ruled out)
  • Involves compression of the victim's neck using fingers, palms, or hands.
  • About 50% of deaths result from vagal inhibition due to pressure on the carotid nerve plexus.
  • Pressure needs to be applied for at least 2 minutes for death to occur.

Mugging (Option B ruled out)
  • Involves compressing the victim's neck using the bend of the elbow or knee.
  • Typically a surprise attack from behind, often leaving minimal injury marks.
  • Also known as a "chokehold," which is prohibited in wrestling due to its danger.

Bansdola (Option C ruled out)
  • A brutal method using a bamboo stick or similar object to crush the neck.
  • Involves tying sticks across the neck or pressing a foot or knee against the throat while lying down.
  • Leaves a distinct bruise across the trachea corresponding to the width of the object used.

Garroting (Option D)
  • Uses a ligature that is tightened by twisting with a lever (Spanish windlass).
  • Causes rapid loss of consciousness and collapse.
  • Historically, it has been used as a method of execution in countries like Spain, Portugal, and Turkey.

questions.text: What is a common characteristic of sexual asphyxia that differentiates it from judicial hanging?

options.label: B
options.text: Use of elaborate setups and self-release mechanisms

questions.correct_answer: B. Use of elaborate setups and self-release mechanisms
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Description

Asphyxia Mechanism

Both involve asphyxia caused by a ligature around the neck.

External Findings

May include a ligature mark, cyanosis, and petechiae.

Aspect

Sexual Asphyxia (Autoerotic Asphyxia)

Judicial Hanging

Intent (Option A ruled out)

Achieve sexual gratification; death is accidental.

Capital punishment; is intended to cause death.

Execution

Involves elaborate setups, bondage, and self-release mechanisms. (Option B)

Highly controlled; specific knot placement (submental) and calculated drop height.

Injuries

Usually less severe; aims to induce hypoxia without fatal damage.

Designed to cause rapid death through forceful cervical spine fracture (hangman‘s fracture-spondylolisthesis of C2 over C3).

Ligature Mark (Option D ruled out)

May be less prominent due to padding; often not distinctive.

Typically distinct, located below the chin or ear.

Cervical Spine Fracture (Option C ruled out)

Rarely occurs.

A hallmark feature.

Scene Findings

Evidence of sexual activity is often present.

Takes place in a controlled environment; no signs of sexual activity.

questions.text: A 30 y/o male is brought to the emergency department after being found hanging from a ceiling fan. On physical examination, which of the following findings is most indicative of antemortem hanging?

options.label: D
options.text: Blue lips and oral mucous membrane

questions.explanation:
Finding

Description

Face

  • Swollen and cyanosed due to impaired venous return.
  • Prominent eyeballs from increased pressure.
  • Dilated pupils (indicative of antemortem hanging).
  • Subconjunctival hemorrhages.
  • Protrusion and swelling of the tongue may show bite marks and small hemorrhages.
  • Bleeding from nose and/or ears.
  • Blue lips and oral mucous membranes.
  • Dribbling of saliva indicates excessive salivation from ligature pressure (indicative of antemortem hanging). (Option B)

Neck

  • Ligature mark ('furrow') typically above the hyoid bone; size/shape depends on ligature material.
  • The skin at the ligature site is initially pale, later yellowish-brown, dry, and parchment-like.
  • Postmortem blisters may appear on the skin near the furrow.
  • Neck veins above the furrow may be distended.
  • The neck becomes slender and elongated due to suspension.
  • Flexed neck to the side opposite the knot.

Other Body Parts

  • Tardieu's spots on the forehead, eyelids, conjunctiva, and temples.
  • Cyanosis of fingernails.
  • Purple postmortem staining in lower limbs (glove and stocking pattern).
  • Clenched hands.
  • Penile turgidity and involuntary semen discharge in males.
  • Involuntary fecal and urine discharge in both sexes.
  • Signs of asphyxia may be absent in complete hanging.

questions.text: A forensic team is called to investigate a case of judicial hanging in an obese individual. The victim was found suspended from a significant height with the knot positioned at the back of the neck. During the autopsy, a transverse tear in the carotid artery is observed, consistent with a long drop hanging. Which of the following findings is most likely associated with this case?
Which of the following is NOT a cause of early death in hanging?

Match the following neck structure compressed with their respective pressures needed to cause death in hanging. 1.Jugular Veins a) 10 kg 2.Carotid Arteries b) 30 kg 3.Trachea c) 2 kg 4.Vertebral Arteries d) 15 kg
questions.explanation:
Neck structure compressed

Compression Pressure

Result

Jugular Veins

2 kg

Venous congestion leading to cessation of cerebral circulation

Carotid Arteries

2.5 - 10 kg

Cerebral anemia/ anoxia

Trachea

15 kg

Asphyxia

Vertebral Arteries

8 - 30 kg

Cerebral anemia/ anoxia

questions.text: In which type of hanging is the knot positioned at the nape of the neck?
